contentrichtext.text: {{Portal|Middle-earth}} In the fiction of [[J. R. R. Tolkien]], the '''Elder Days''' are the first [[Ages of Middle-earth]]. During the [[Second Age|Second]] and [[Third Age]], the term referred to the [[First Age]] and before, but in the [[Fourth Age]] the term began to be applied to all three ages which came before: a time before the dominance of [[Man (Middle-earth)|Men]] and the dwindling of the [[Elf (Middle-earth)|Elves]] and other races.<ref name="rotkb">{{ME-ref|RotK|"Appendix B The Tale of Years"}}</ref> ==Computer users' slang== In some computer users' slang "the Elder Days" means the period before about 1980, before many modern computer developments started.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Schell |last2=Dodge |first1=Bernadette Hlubik |first2=John L.|title=The Hacking of America: Who's Doing It, Why, and how|year=2002|pages=23,26}}</ref> This usage started among computer programmers who were familiar with Tolkien's writings. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.lotrlibrary.com/MT/emt.asp The Elder Days Timeline: Lord of the Rings Library] {{Middle-earth}} [[Category:Middle-earth eras]] {{MiddleEarth-stub}}
